text:
Every day it feels like
I'm fighting my brain.

Thank you so much for coming on
the tour. Let's go and get a beer!
APPLAUSE
Stop it!

I think frustration
is a huge part of my life,

because every day is a bit of
a kind of task to get through it
and not to mess up massively.

You know, you forget your keys,
you forget your wallet.
Being late for work.

The amount of times
I've missed parties

that my friends have organised
months in advance.
It feels like a tombola, right,

where every day
there's a million things

in this tombola ball, right,
that need to be done,

or things I need to remember -
you know, text your mate,

or, you know,
it's your mate's birthday,

or you need to eat,
or you need to get a coffee tank.
These sort of things.

And my body will kind
of spit a ball out.

How do you feel about
this, then?
I'm excited to see it.

I'm really... I've heard
a couple of little nuggets,

but, no, nothing, really.
So I'm intrigued.
OK, let's run with it. Yeah.
BEEPING
BEEPING CONTINUES

Ooh, you're supposed
to see your parents in...
..half an hour.
Oh, God.
You're going to be very late.

So, that's Tombola Man.
He's what I call my ADHD.

He's constantly
feeding me instructions.
TOMBOLA MAN LAUGHS

But it's like he's choosing them
completely randomly.

You do need
to do your bike insurance,
and now seems like the perfect time.
Sometimes...they're helpful.
And sometimes...
..not so much.
Do you see what I mean?
Oh, and before that,

why don't we go over Henry's
top-ten cringiest moments?
Henry?

You see, every day it feels
like I'm fighting my brain

just to get through
the very basic of tasks.

Oh, and you need
to send that email to Julie.

Your boss already thinks
you're an idiot.

Sometimes this constant
barrage sends me into a spiral.

It feels like I'm trapped
in a riptide,

trying to keep my head above water
whilst he drags me down.
You are an idiot.
You haven't texted your mum back,
or your dad, or your mates.
Some days it's really hard to cope,
and my brain just won't work at all.
You are such an embarrassment...
You are the epitome of...
Messy...
You're late...
You're the worst human ever...
Go to bed...
Messy...
Biggest waste of space...
See, ADHD sometimes
has me embarrassed...
..well, ashamed.
I'm scared you're ashamed too?
See, I don't need fixing.
This is me.

See, my path through life
is going to be...different.

And I'd love for you to be
alongside with me all the way.
We just might take some detours.
All good? You did very well.

Yeah? I'll take that.
Excellent. It's incredible.

Well done, love. That was...
Yeah, that's good.
Very articulate. Well done.
It's so good. Yeah?

So brilliant.
Oh. Thank you. I love you.

I think I was aware,
we were aware, that, you know,
there's a lot of stuff going on -

you know, there's a lot of noise
in your head -
perhaps not to that volume.
I think what I didn't know

is just quite how much
it's affecting you emotionally.
I mean, this is incredibly naive,

but I only thought that
ADHD would affect school.

I just don't think
I thought beyond that.
Yeah. And...
And not realising that there are...
You know, there are so many things

that you have to be able
to accomplish, you know,
just to do your daily life.

I've been scared
to tell you guys that.

I didn't want you guys
to think it was something

that you had to kind
of pick up and put back together.

I'm really sorry
about that.
No. No, no, no.

That's not what
I want you to be, sorry.

No, but, you know, that
sense of "we're trying to fix you".

The bit I'm really struggling with
is the sort of shame thing,
because we're so, so proud of you.

I know, yeah. We just think
you're amazing. Yeah.

You've grown so much,
and, like, that's amazing.
And we will always be there.

Thank you. I know.
I appreciate you.

Honestly, I could float
through the ceiling.

That's great.
I feel so much better. Yeah.
So how do you feel it went, then?

They were really...
Really, really well. Really well.
Sincerely, one of the most...

..yeah, beautiful conversations
I've had with them to do with this.
It feels... I don't know,

it feels like I've taken
the frost off a windshield.

Mission accomplished.
Mission accomplished.
